A **dwarvish iron helm** is a type of [helm](/wiki/Helm "Helm") that appears in *[NetHack](/wiki/NetHack "NetHack")*. It is made of [iron](/wiki/Iron "Iron"), and appears as a **hard hat** when unidentified.

[ ]

## Contents

- [1 Generation](#Generation)

- [2 Description](#Description)

- [3 Strategy](#Strategy)

- [4 History](#History)

- [5 Variants](#Variants)

  - [5.1 SLASH'EM](#SLASH.27EM)
  - [5.2 UnNetHack](#UnNetHack)
  - [5.3 dNetHack](#dNetHack)
  - [5.4 EvilHack](#EvilHack)
  - [5.5 SlashTHEM](#SlashTHEM)
  - [5.6 Hack'EM](#Hack.27EM)

- [6 References](#References)

## Generation

[Dwarven](/wiki/Dwarf_\(starting_race\) "Dwarf (starting race)") characters start the game with knowledge of the dwarvish iron helm, and any dwarven character in a role that starts the game with a [helmet](/wiki/Helmet "Helmet") will start with a dwarvish iron helm instead, though there are no applicable roles where this substitution occurs.[\[1\]](#cite_note-1)

In addition to random generation, armor [shops](/wiki/Shop "Shop") and general stores can stock dwarvish iron helms.

Live [dwarves](/wiki/Dwarf_\(monster_attribute\) "Dwarf (monster attribute)") have a 1⁄4 chance of [being generated with](/wiki/Monster_starting_inventory "Monster starting inventory") a dwarvish iron helm.[\[2\]](#cite_note-2)

## Description

While worn, a dwarvish iron helm grants a base [AC](/wiki/AC "AC") of 2.

## Strategy

The dwarvish iron helm is the only helm with 2 AC, and is usually the best helm available in the early- and mid-game for builds that are not significantly reliant on [spellcasting](/wiki/Spellcasting "Spellcasting"). It is also among heavy and susceptible to [rust traps](/wiki/Rust_trap "Rust trap") and [rust monsters](/wiki/Rust_monster "Rust monster"), making [rustproofing](/wiki/Rustproof "Rustproof") necessary to preserve its AC.

In the mid-game, the dwarvish iron helm is often discarded in favor of other helms that provide additional benefits beyond the basics, especially for [ascension kits](/wiki/Ascension_kit "Ascension kit"): the [helm of telepathy](/wiki/Helm_of_telepathy "Helm of telepathy") and the [helm of brilliance](/wiki/Helm_of_brilliance "Helm of brilliance") are particular candidates. The [elven leather helm](/wiki/Elven_leather_helm "Elven leather helm") is also a somewhat common replacement - while it does not protect your head from falling objects, they do not interfere with spellcasting and can safely be enchanted to +7; falling objects are also rarely a concern beyond the early game.

## History

The dwarvish iron helm first appears in [NetHack 3.0.0](/wiki/NetHack_3.0.0 "NetHack 3.0.0").

## Variants

In variants with [object materials](/wiki/Object_materials "Object materials") systems, a dwarvish iron helm is sometimes called a **dwarvish helm**, with iron as its base material - they may also have their material appended within the name, depending on the variant (e.g., "a +0 dwarvish [mithril](/wiki/Mithril "Mithril") helm").

Some variants may give dwarves (including the player character) an AC bonus for wearing a dwarvish iron helm.

### SLASH'EM

In [SLASH'EM](/wiki/SLASH%27EM "SLASH'EM"), dwarven [Knights](/wiki/Knight "Knight") that start the game with a helmet will instead start with a +0 dwarvish iron helm, making use of the existing substitution.

A dwarvish iron helm can be [upgraded](/wiki/Upgraded "Upgraded") to a helm of telepathy or a helm of brilliance. Upgrading an [orcish helm](/wiki/Orcish_helm "Orcish helm"), helm of telepathy or helm of brilliance will produce a dwarvish iron helm.

### UnNetHack

In [UnNetHack](/wiki/UnNetHack "UnNetHack"), the dwarvish iron helm grants +1 AC to dwarves that wear them, including player dwarves.

### dNetHack

In [dNetHack](/wiki/DNetHack "DNetHack"), a dwarvish helm grants 1 AC and 1 [DR](/wiki/DR "DR") while worn, and has a built-in [lantern](/wiki/Lantern "Lantern") that can be turned on or off by [applying](/wiki/Apply "Apply") the helm. Dwarves that generate in dark levels within the [Gnomish Mines](/wiki/Gnomish_Mines "Gnomish Mines") will have their helm's lantern lit.

### EvilHack

In [EvilHack](/wiki/EvilHack "EvilHack"), the dwarvish helm grants +1 AC to dwarves that wear them, including player dwarves. Dwarven Knights start the game with a +0 dwarvish helm in place of the standard helmet.

[Croesus](/wiki/Croesus "Croesus") has a 1⁄2 chance of generating with a [golden](/wiki/Gold_\(material\) "Gold (material)") dwarvish helm.

A dwarvish helm can be created at a [forge](/wiki/Forge_\(dungeon_feature\) "Forge (dungeon feature)") by combining a [dwarvish short sword](/wiki/Dwarvish_short_sword "Dwarvish short sword") and a [helmet](/wiki/Helmet "Helmet"); a dwarvish helm can also be combined with a [large shield](/wiki/Large_shield "Large shield") to create a [dwarvish roundshield](/wiki/Dwarvish_roundshield "Dwarvish roundshield").

### SlashTHEM

In [SlashTHEM](/wiki/SlashTHEM "SlashTHEM"), in addition to SLASH'EM details, dwarven [Paladins](/wiki/Paladin_\(role\) "Paladin (role)") start the game with a +0 dwarvish iron helm in place of the standard helmet.

### Hack'EM

In [Hack'EM](/wiki/Hack%27EM "Hack'EM"), the dwarvish iron helm grants +1 AC to dwarves that wear them, including player dwarves. Dwarven [Undead Slayers](/wiki/Undead_Slayer "Undead Slayer") that start the game with a helmet will instead start with a +0 dwarvish iron helm.

Upgrading an orcish helm will produce a dwarvish helm as in SLASH'EM, but upgrading a dwarvish helm will only produce an orcish helm. Forging recipes and other details are the same as in SLASH'EM and EvilHack.

## References

1. [↑](#cite_ref-1) [src/u\_init.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 226](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.7_Released/src/u_init.c#L226): *Race-based substitutions for initial inventory*
2. [↑](#cite_ref-2) [src/makemon.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 381](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.7_Released/src/makemon.c#L381): *default dwarvish armor*
